channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shinzo Abe’s Call for Early Elections in Japan Is Prompted by Fear, Analysts Say
item.description: The Japanese prime minister’s pledge to dissolve Parliament and hold national elections next month reflects worries that his economic revival program and his popularity are falling, experts say.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Russia’s Farmers See Opportunity After Ban on Western Food Imports
item.description: With often cheaper imports unavailable, some agricultural activists hope to see a boost in local farming, but for consumers the self-imposed sanctions have so far served mostly to raise food prices.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boris Akimov, who runs LavkaLavka, an organic farm cooperative, hopes that with the ban on Western imports, Russians will explore local foods.

item.title: Obama Orders Review of Hostage Policy
item.description: The review includes how the government deals with hostage’s relatives, some of whom have complained about the administration refusal to pay ransoms.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Umbrellas Come Out at Hong Kong Graduation Ceremonies
item.description: The president of Hong Kong Baptist University, Albert Chan, refused to hand out diplomas to students who carried umbrellas onto the stage during graduation ceremonies.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Global Number of Youths Is Highest Ever, U.N. Reports
item.description: A United Nations report said the fate of the world’s adolescent population depended on governments’ ability to provide health care, education and jobs.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Farming on Water to Prevent the Effects of Climate Change
item.description: Farms — with a duck coop, fish enclosures and a vegetable farm moored to the riverbank — are helping Bangladeshis live with rising waters.
item.dc:creator: By AMY YEE
item.media:description: Villagers in northwest Bangladesh tending a floating farm.

item.title: Senegal Helps Plant a Great Green Wall to Fend Off the Desert
item.description: Overgrazing and climate change are the major causes of the desert’s advance. Eleven countries are planting trees in a 4,400-mile long belt to fend off its encroachment.
item.dc:creator: By DIANA S. POWERS
item.media:description: Women working in a drip-irrigated garden in Widou Thiengoly, Senegal.

item.title: From an Egyptian-American Prisoner on Hunger Strike in Cairo, a Letter Home
item.description: Mohamed Soltan, who has been incarcerated for more than a year since his arrest at a street protest, wrote to his family on his 27th birthday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Special Report: Business of Green: Asia Pushes Hard for Clean Energy
item.description: More than $250 billion a year will pour into renewable energy generation, two-thirds of Asia’s power investment, but the use of fossil fuels is also growing.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BETH GARDINER
item.media:description: Turbines in China are expected to produce nearly two and a half times the entire power generating capacity of Britain by 2020, but many wind farms are too far from areas that need the energy most.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What ‘Democracy’ Means in China Is Not What Australia’s Abbott Thinks
item.description: An awkward moment ensued after Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia mistakenly praised President Xi Jinping of China for a commitment to democracy that Mr. Xi never made.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, left, and Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia at an official banquet in Canberra. Mr. Abbott referred to China in his toast as Tasmania but immediately corrected himself.

item.title: Four Rabbis Are Killed in Jerusalem Synagogue Attack
item.description: The four men, including three Americans, were left dead after two Palestinian assailants armed with a gun, knives and axes stormed a West Jerusalem synagogue. The attackers were shot and killed by police.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Supporters of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine in Gaza celebrated the attack on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Premiere of ‘Hunger Games’ Film Postponed in China
item.description: The release of “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 1″ was scheduled for Friday but has now been pushed back to early next year. No official reason for the delay has been announced.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A scene from "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1," with Liam Hemsworth and Jennifer Lawrence, front, whose release in China has been postponed from this Friday to next year.

item.title: Thailand Is Searching for Scores of Uighurs Who Fled China
item.description: The escapees, almost all women and children, left a shelter in southern Thailand in several separate groups this month, and about 120 remain at large.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Deaths Linked to Terrorism Are Up 60 Percent, Study Finds
item.description: The report by the nonprofit Institute for Economics and Peace comes as Western governments try to reverse gains by militants in Syria and Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Flying Feckless in Karachi
item.description: A malaise has struck Pakistan International Airlines, once a national asset with crack pilots and sound management.
item.dc:creator: By BINA SHAH

item.title: Suicide Attack in Afghan Capital Kills 2
item.description: A truck laden with gravel and explosives detonated near the gate of a base for foreign contract workers in Kabul on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Bear That Became the Symbol of a Movement Dies
item.description: Oliver, as the bear was called, was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia after spending 30 years in bear-bile farms. His dramatic journey to a new life was captured in the documentary “Cages of Shame.”
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Oliver was a brown bear who was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia from a bile farm in the province of Shandong, along with nine other bears.

item.title: North Korea Seeks to Host a Weight Lifting Event
item.description: North Korea is in talks to hold a world championship weight lifting event, although a International Weightlifting Federation official said a junior event was more likely than one at the senior level.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN OLIVER
item.media:description: Om Yun-chol of North Korea at the Asian Games in September.

item.title: Push in U.N. to Intercept Jihadists’ Oil
item.description: A United Nations panel urges the seizure of oil trucks entering and leaving territory controlled by jihadists in Iraq and Syria and a moratorium on antiquities sales from those countries.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: E.U. to Toughen Sanctions on Ukrainian Separatists, but Not Russia
item.description: The bloc decided to widen sanctions on individuals in Ukraine while pushing for a diplomatic solution to Russia’s involvement there.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Hong Kong Clears an Area of Pro-Democracy Protesters
item.description: The authorities met no resistance, with student protesters saying they would not oppose a court order to remove barricades around a tower near government headquarters.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Workers removed a barricade after a court injunction to clear part of a pro-democracy protest site in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: DealBook: Link Opens Between Hong Kong and Shanghai Stock Markets
item.description: The connection will strengthen the two cities’ roles as global financial centers and open the door to $4.2 trillion pool of capital.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: The Hong Kong exchange rang in a pilot program with Shanghai’s exchange.

item.title: Critic's Notebook: Berlin After the Wall: A Microcosm of the World’s Chaotic Change
item.description: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the city’s identity is still a work in progress.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Left, Edwin Reichert/Associated Press; Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Potsdamer Platz in 1962, left, isolated by the Berlin Wall, and this year, after efforts to develop it.

item.title: Prague Journal: Reverently and Defiantly, Czechs Honor Velvet Revolution’s Anniversary
item.description: In Prague, some Czechs celebrated by pelting President Milos Zeman with debris as he unveiled a new memorial at a university campus.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Czechs lit candles at a memorial in Prague on Monday, the 25th anniversary of the start of the Velvet Revolution that ended 41 years of Communist rule.

item.title: Coal Rush in India Could Tip Balance on Climate Change
item.description: The country has a voracious and growing demand for energy, and officials see coal as the best way forward. However, experts predict dire consequences.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers last month at a strip mine in Jharkhand, India. India’s coal rush could push the world past the brink of irreversible climate change, with India among the worst affected countries, scientists say.
